The second element of a diphthong {{IPA|/i u/}} was often pronounced as a doubled semivowel {{IPA|[jj ww]}} or {{IPA|[jː wː]}} before vowels, and in other cases it was often [[elision|lost]]:<ref name="Allen diphthong vowel" /> * {{lang|grc|Ἀθηναῖοι}} {{IPA|/a.tʰɛɛ.nái.oi/}} ('Athenians'): {{IPA|[a.tʰɛː.naĵ.joi]}} * {{lang|grc|ποιῶ}} {{IPA|/poi.ɔ́ɔ/}} ('I do'): either {{IPA|[poj.jɔ̂ː]}} or {{IPA|[po.jɔ̂ː]}}<!-- Examples from meter of Athenian tragedy needed. --> * Doric {{lang|grc|[[stoa|στοιᾱ́]]}} {{IPA|/stoi.aá/}}: {{IPA|[sto.jǎː]}} : Attic {{lang|grc|στοᾱ́}} {{IPA|/sto.aá/}}: {{IPA|[sto.ǎː]}} * {{lang|grc|κελεύω}} {{IPA|/ke.leú.ɔː/}} ('I command'): {{IPA|[ke.lew̌.wɔː]}} * {{lang|grc|σημεῖον}} {{IPA|/sɛɛ.méi.on/}} ('sign'): {{IPA|[sɛː.meĵ.jon]}}
The diphthong {{IPA|/oi/}} merged with the long close front rounded vowel {{IPA|/yː/}} in Koine. It likely first became {{IPA|[øi]}}. Change to {{IPA|[øi]}} would be [[assimilation (linguistics)|assimilation]]: the back vowel {{IPA|[o]}} becoming front {{IPA|[ø]}} because of the following front vowel {{IPA|[i]}}. This may have been the pronunciation in Classical Attic. Later it must have become {{IPA|[øː]}}, parallel to the monophthongization of {{IPA|/ei ou/}}, and then {{IPA|[yː]}}, but when words with {{angbr|{{lang|grc|οι}}}} were borrowed into Latin, the Greek digraph was represented with the Latin digraph {{angbr|{{sqc|oe}}}}, representing the diphthong {{IPA|/oe/}}.<ref name="Allen short diphthong" />
[[Thucydides]] reports the confusion of two words ([[s:History of the Peloponnesian War/Book 2#2:54|2:54]]), which makes more sense if {{IPA|/oi/}} was pronounced {{IPA|[øi]}}:<ref name="Allen short diphthong" /> *{{lang|grc|λοιμός}} {{IPA|/loi.mós/}} ('plague'): possibly {{IPA|[løi.mós]}} :{{lang|grc|λῑμός}} {{IPA|/lii.mós/}} ('famine'): {{IPA|[liː.mós]}}
In the diphthongs {{IPA|/au̯ eu̯ ɛːu̯/}}, the offglide {{IPA|/u/}} became a consonant in Koine Greek, and they became Modern Greek {{IPA|/av ev iv/}}. The long diphthongs {{IPA|/aːi̯ ɛːi̯ ɔːi̯/}} lost their offglide and merged with the long vowels {{IPA|/aː ɛː ɔː/}} by the time of Koine Greek.
==Spelling== [[Archaic Greek alphabets|Many different forms of the Greek alphabet]] were used for the regional dialects of the Greek language during the Archaic and early Classical periods. The Attic dialect, however, used two forms. The first was the [[Archaic Greek alphabets#Old Attic|Old Attic alphabet]], and the second is the Ionic alphabet, introduced to [[Athens]] around the end of the 5th century BC during the [[archon]]ship of [[Eucleides]]. The last is the standard alphabet in modern editions of Ancient Greek texts, and the one used for Classical Attic, standard Koine, and Medieval Greek, finally developing into the alphabet used for Modern Greek.
===Consonant spelling=== Most double consonants are written using double letters: {{angbr|{{lang|grc|ππ σσ ρρ}}}} represent {{IPA|/pː sː rː/}} or {{IPA|/pp ss rr/}}. The geminate versions of the aspirated stops {{IPA|/pʰː tʰː kʰː/}} are written with the digraphs {{angbr|{{lang|grc|πφ τθ κχ}}}},<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1987|p=21|loc=doubling of aspirates}}</ref> and geminate {{IPA|/ɡː/}} is written as {{angbr|{{lang|grc|κγ}}}}, since {{angbr|{{lang|grc|γγ}}}} represents {{IPA|[ŋɡ]}} in the standard orthography of Ancient Greek.<ref name="Allen g">{{Harvnb|Allen|1987|pp=35–39}}</ref> *{{lang|grc|ἔκγονος}} ({{lang|grc|ἐκ-γονος}}) {{IPA|/éɡ.ɡo.nos/}} ('offspring'), occasionally {{lang|grc|{{sm|εγγονοσ}}}} in inscriptions :{{lang|grc|ἐγγενής}} {{IPA|/eŋ.ɡe.nɛɛ́s/}} ('inborn') ({{lang|grc|εν-γενής}})
{{IPA|/s/}} was written with [[sigma]] {{angbr|{{lang|grc|Σ σ ς}}}}. The clusters {{IPA|/ps ks/}} were written as {{angbr|{{lang|grc|{{sc|ΦΣ ΧΣ}}}}}} in the [[Archaic Greek alphabets#Old Attic|Old Attic alphabet]], but as {{angbr|{{lang|grc|{{sc|Ψ Ξ}}}}}} in the standard Ionic alphabet.
Voiceless {{IPA|/r/}} is usually written with the ''spiritus asper'' as {{lang|grc|ῥ-}} and transcribed as ''rh'' in Latin. The same orthography is sometimes encountered when {{IPA|/r/}} is geminated, as in {{angbr|{{lang|grc|συρρέω}}}}, sometimes written {{angbr|{{lang|grc|συῤῥέω}}}}, giving rise to the transliteration ''rrh''. This example also illustrates that {{IPA|/n/}} ({{lang|grc|συν-ῥέω}}) assimilates to following {{IPA|/r/}}, creating gemination.
===Vowel spelling=== The [[Close front rounded vowel|close front rounded]] vowels {{IPA|/y/}} and {{IPA|/yː/}} (an evolution of {{IPA|/u/}} and {{IPA|/uː/}} respectively) are both represented in writing by the letter [[upsilon]] ({{lang|grc|υ}}) irrespective of length.
In Classical Attic, the spellings {{lang|grc|ει}} and {{lang|grc|ου}} represented respectively the vowels {{IPA|/eː/}} and {{IPA|/uː/}} (the latter being an evolution of {{IPA|/oː/}}), from [[#Monophthongization|original diphthongs]], [[#Compensatory lengthening|compensatory lengthening]], or [[#Contraction|contraction]].
The above information about the usage of the vowel letters applies to the classical orthography of Attic, after Athens took over the orthographic conventions of the Ionic alphabet in 403 BC. In the earlier, traditional Attic orthography there was only a smaller repertoire of vowel symbols: {{lang|grc|α}}, {{lang|grc|ε}}, {{lang|grc|ι}}, {{lang|grc|ο}}, and {{lang|grc|υ}}. The letters {{lang|grc|η}} and {{lang|grc|ω}} were still missing. All five vowel symbols could at that stage denote either a long or a short vowel. Moreover, the letters {{lang|grc|ε}} and {{lang|grc|ο}} could respectively denote the long open-mid {{IPA|/ɛː, ɔː/}}, the long close-mid {{IPA|/eː, oː/}} and the short mid phonemes {{IPA|/e, o/}}. The Ionic alphabet brought the new letters {{lang|grc|η}} and {{lang|grc|ω}} for the one set of long vowels, and the convention of using the digraph spellings {{lang|grc|ει}} and {{lang|grc|ου}} for the other, leaving simple {{lang|grc|ε}} and {{lang|grc|ο}} to be used only for the short vowels. However, the remaining vowel letters {{lang|grc|α}}, {{lang|grc|ι}} and {{lang|grc|υ}} continued to be ambiguous between long and short phonemes.
===Spelling of /h/=== In the Old Attic alphabet, {{IPA|/h/}} was written with the letterform of [[eta]] {{angbr|{{lang|grc|{{sc|Η}}}}}}. In the Ionic dialect of Asia Minor, {{IPA|/h/}} was lost early on, and the letter {{angbr|{{lang|grc|{{sc|Η}}}}}} in the Ionic alphabet represented {{IPA|/ɛː/}}. In 403 BC, when the Ionic alphabet was adopted in Athens, the sound {{IPA|/h/}} ceased to be represented in writing.
In some inscriptions {{IPA|/h/}} was represented by a symbol formed from the left-hand half of the original letter: {{angbr|{{lang|grc|{{sc|Ͱ}}}}}} ({{GrGl|Eta tack}}). Later grammarians, during the time of the Hellenistic Koine, developed that symbol further into a [[diacritic]], the rough breathing ({{lang|grc|δασὺ πνεῦμα}}; {{lang-la|spiritus asper}}; {{lang|grc|δασεῖα}} for short), which was written on the top of the initial vowel. Correspondingly, they introduced the [[mirror image]] diacritic called smooth breathing ({{lang|grc|ψιλὸν πνεῦμα}}; {{lang-la|spiritus lenis}}; {{lang|grc|ψιλή}} for short), which indicated the absence of {{IPA|/h/}}. These marks were not used consistently until the time of the [[Byzantine Empire]].
==Phonotactics== Ancient Greek words were divided into syllables. A word has one syllable for every short vowel, long vowel, or diphthong. In addition, syllables began with a consonant if possible, and sometimes ended with a consonant. Consonants at the beginning of the syllable are the syllable onset, the vowel in the middle is a nucleus, and the consonant at the end is a coda.
In dividing words into syllables, each vowel or diphthong belongs to one syllable. A consonant between vowels goes with the following vowel.<ref>{{Harvnb|Smyth|1920|loc=§138, 140: syllables, vowels, and intervocalic consonants}}</ref> In the following transcriptions, a period {{angbr|{{IPA|.}}}} separates syllables. * {{lang|grc|λέγω}} ('I say'): {{IPA|/lé.ɡɔɔ/}} (two syllables) * {{lang|grc|τοιαῦται}} ('this kind') ({{sm|fem pl}}): {{IPA|/toi.áu.tai/}} (three syllables) * {{lang|grc|βουλεύσειε}} ('if only he would want'): {{IPA|/buː.leú.sei.e/}} (four syllables) * {{lang|grc|ἠελίοιο}} ('sun's') (Homeric Greek): {{IPA|/ɛɛ.e.lí.oi.o/}} (five syllables)
Any remaining consonants are added at the end of a syllable. And when a double consonant occurs between vowels, it is divided between syllables. One half of the double consonant goes to the previous syllable, forming a coda, and one goes to the next, forming an onset. Clusters of two or three consonants are also usually divided between syllables, with at least one consonant joining the previous vowel and forming the syllable coda of its syllable, but see below. * {{lang|grc|ἄλλος}} ('another'): {{IPA|/ál.los/}} * {{lang|grc|ἔστιν}} ('there is'): {{IPA|/és.tin/}} * {{lang|grc|δόξα}} ('opinion'): {{IPA|/dók.sa/}} * {{lang|grc|ἐχθρός}} ('enemy'): {{IPA|/ekʰ.tʰrós/}}
===Syllable weight=== Syllables in Ancient Greek were either [[syllable weight|light or heavy]]. This distinction is important in [[Ancient Greek poetry]], which was made up of patterns of heavy and light syllables. [[Syllable weight]] is based on both consonants and vowels. Ancient Greek accent, by contrast, is only based on vowels.
A syllable ending in a short vowel, or the diphthongs {{lang|grc|αι}} and {{lang|grc|οι}} in certain noun and verb endings, was light. All other syllables were heavy: that is, syllables ending in a long vowel or diphthong, a short vowel and consonant, or a long vowel or diphthong and consonant. * {{lang|grc|λέγω}} {{IPA|/lé.ɡɔɔ/}}: light – heavy; * {{lang|grc|τοιαῦται}} {{IPA|/toi.áu.tai/}}: heavy – heavy – light; * {{lang|grc|βουλεύσειε}} {{IPA|/buː.leú.sei.e/}}: heavy – heavy – heavy – light; * {{lang|grc|ἠελίοιο}} {{IPA|/ɛɛ.e.lí.oi.o/}}: heavy – light – light – heavy – light.
Greek grammarians called heavy syllables {{lang|grc|μακραί}} ('long', singular {{lang|grc|μακρά}}), and placed them in two categories. They called a syllable with a long vowel or diphthong {{lang|grc|φύσει μακρά}} ('long by nature'), and a syllable ending in a consonant {{lang|grc|θέσει μακρά}} ('long by position'). These terms were translated into Latin as ''{{lang|la|naturā longa}}'' and ''{{lang|la|positiōne longa}}''. However, Indian grammarians distinguished vowel length and syllable weight by using the terms ''heavy'' and ''light'' for syllable quantity and the terms ''long'' and ''short'' only for vowel length.<ref name="Allen syllable">{{Harvnb|Allen|1987|pp=104, 105|loc=terms for syllable quantity}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1973|pp=53–55|loc=''heavy'' or ''long'' versus ''light'' or ''short''}}</ref> This article adopts their terminology, since not all metrically heavy syllables have long vowels; e.g.: * {{lang|grc|ἥ}} ({{sm|fem [[relative pronoun|rel pron]]}}) {{IPA|/hɛɛ́/}} is a heavy syllable having a long vowel, "long by nature"; * {{lang|grc|οἷ}} ({{sm|masc dat sg [[personal pronoun|pron]]}}) {{IPA|/hói/}} is a heavy syllable having a diphthong, "long by nature"; * {{lang|grc|ὅς}} ({{sm|masc rel pron}}) {{IPA|/hós/}} is a heavy syllable ending in a consonant, "long by position".
Poetic meter shows which syllables in a word counted as heavy, and knowing syllable weight allows us to determine how consonant clusters were divided between syllables. Syllables before double consonants, and most syllables before consonant clusters, count as heavy. Here the letters {{angbr|{{lang|grc|ζ, ξ and ψ}}}} count as consonant clusters. This indicates that double consonants and most consonant clusters were divided between syllables, with at least the first consonant belonging to the preceding syllable.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1987|pp=105, 106|loc=syllable division}}</ref> *{{lang|grc|ἄλλος}} {{IPA|/ál.los/}} ('different'): heavy – heavy *{{lang|grc|ὥστε}} {{IPA|/hɔɔ́s.te/}} ('so that'): heavy – light *{{lang|grc|ἄξιος}} {{IPA|/ák.si.os/}} ('worthy'): heavy – light – heavy *{{lang|grc|προσβλέψαιμι}} {{IPA|/pros.blép.sai.mi/}} ('may I see!'): heavy – heavy – heavy – light *{{lang|grc|χαριζομένη}} {{IPA|/kʰa.ris.do.mé.nɛɛ/}} ('rejoicing' {{sm|fem sg}}): light – heavy – light – light – heavy
In Attic poetry, syllables before a cluster of a stop and a liquid or nasal are commonly light rather than heavy. This was called ''{{lang|la|correptio Attica}}'' ('Attic shortening'), since here an ordinarily "long" syllable became "short".<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1987|pp=106–110|loc=correptio Attica}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1973|pp=210–216|loc=syllable weight before consonant sequences inside words}}</ref> *{{lang|grc|πατρός}} ('of a father'): Homeric {{IPA|/pat.rós/}} (heavy-heavy), Attic {{IPA|/pa.trós/}} (light-heavy)
===Onset=== In Attic Greek, any single consonant and many [[consonant cluster]]s can occur as a [[Syllable#Onset|syllable onset]] (the beginning of a syllable). Certain consonant clusters occur as onsets, while others do not occur.
Six stop clusters occur. All of them agree in [[voice-onset time]], and begin with a labial or velar and end with a dental. Thus, the clusters {{IPA|/pʰtʰ kʰtʰ pt kt bd ɡd/}} are allowed. Certain stop clusters do not occur as onsets: clusters beginning with a dental and ending with a labial or velar, and clusters of stops that disagree in voice onset time.<ref name="Goldstein">{{Harvnb|Goldstein|2014}}</ref>

===Coda=== In Ancient Greek, any vowel may end a word, but the only consonants that may normally [[Syllable#Coda|end a word]] are {{IPA|/n r s/}}. If a stop ended a word in Proto-Indo-European, this was dropped in Ancient Greek, as in {{lang|grc|ποίημα}} (from {{lang|grc|ποίηματ}}; compare the genitive singular ποιήματος). Other consonants may end a word, however, when a final vowel is elided before a word beginning in a vowel, as in {{lang|grc|ἐφ᾿ ἵππῳ}} (from {{lang|grc|ἐπὶ ἵππῳ}}).
==Accent== {{Main article|Ancient Greek accent}} Ancient Greek had a pitch accent, unlike the stress accent of Modern Greek and English. One [[mora (linguistics)|mora]] of a word was accented with high pitch. A mora is a unit of vowel length; in Ancient Greek, short vowels have one mora and long vowels and diphthongs have two morae. Thus, a one-mora vowel could have accent on its one mora, and a two-mora vowel could have accent on either of its two morae. The position of accent was free, with certain limitations. In a given word, it could appear in several different positions, depending on the lengths of the vowels in the word.
In the examples below, long vowels and diphthongs are represented with two vowel symbols, one for each mora. This does not mean that the long vowel has two separate vowels in different syllables. Syllables are separated by periods {{angbr|.}}; anything between two periods is pronounced in one syllable. *{{lang|grc|η}} (long vowel with two morae): phonemic transcription {{IPA|/ɛɛ/}}, phonetic transcription {{IPA|[ɛː]}} (one syllable) *{{lang|grc|εε}} (two short vowels with one mora each): phonemic transcription {{IPA|/e.e/}}, phonetic transcription {{IPA|[e̞.e̞]}} (two syllables)
The accented mora is marked with acute accent {{angbr|´}}. A vowel with rising pitch contour is marked with a caron {{angbr|ˇ}}, and a vowel with a falling pitch contour is marked with a circumflex {{angbr|ˆ}}.
The position of the accent in Ancient Greek was phonemic and distinctive: certain words are distinguished by which mora in them is accented. The position of the accent was also distinctive on long vowels and diphthongs: either the first or the second mora could be accented. Phonetically, a two-mora vowel had a rising or falling [[pitch contour]], depending on which of its two morae was accented:<ref name="Kiparsky" /><ref name="Allen accent">{{Harvnb|Allen|1987|pp=116–124|loc=accent}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! colspan="2" | ! colspan="9" | Examples of pitch accent |- ! colspan="2" | Greek | {{lang|grc|τόμος}} || {{lang|grc|τομός}} || {{lang|grc|εἶμι}} || {{lang|grc|εἴτε}} || {{lang|grc|εἰμί}} || {{lang|grc|ἦτε}} || {{lang|grc|ἤτε}} || {{lang|grc|οἶκοι}} || {{lang|grc|οἴκοι}} |- ! colspan="2" | translation | 'a slice' || 'sharp' || 'I go' || 'either' || 'I am'<!-- Pausal form. --> || 'you were' || 'or' || 'houses' || 'at home' |- ! rowspan="2" | IPA ! phonemic | rowspan="2" | {{IPA|/tó.mos/}} | rowspan="2" | {{IPA|/to.mós/}} | {{IPA|/éi.mi/}}<!-- With /ei/ because it comes from the root /i/; next example comes from root /es/. Both pronounced with [ee] in Attic. --> || {{IPA|/eé.te/}} | rowspan="2" | {{IPA|/eː.mí/}} | {{IPA|/ɛ́ɛ.te/}} | {{IPA|/ɛɛ́.te/}} || {{IPA|/ói.koi/}} || {{IPA|/oí.koi/}} |- ! phonetic | {{IPA|[êː.mi]}} || {{IPA|[ěː.te]}} || {{IPA|[ɛ̂ː.te]}} || {{IPA|[ɛ̌ː.te]}} || {{IPA|[oî.koi]}} || {{IPA|[oǐ.koi]}} |} <!--Final {{lang|grc|-αι, οι}} were sometimes considered long, and sometimes short. This sometimes explains accentual differences between forms:<ref>{{Harvnb|Smyth|1920|loc=§169: short αι οι}}</ref> * A description of the ultima-length accent rule is needed to explain this. -->
[[Greek diacritics|Accent marks]] were never used until around 200 BC. They were first used in [[Alexandria]], and [[Aristophanes of Byzantium]] is said to have invented them.<ref>{{Harnvb|Smyth|1920|loc=§161}}</ref> There are three: the [[acute accent|acute]], [[circumflex]], and [[grave accent|grave]] {{angbr|{{lang|grc|´ ῀ `}}}}. The shape of the circumflex is a merging of the acute and grave.<ref>{{Harvnb|Smyth|1920|loc=§156: the circumflex and its pronunciation}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Robins|1993|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=hTZHbNmFfpsC&pg=PA50 50]}}</ref>
The acute represented high or rising pitch, the circumflex represented falling pitch, but what the grave represented is uncertain.<ref name="Allen accent marks">{{Harvnb|Allen|1987|pp=124–126|loc=accent marks and their meanings}}</ref> Early on, the grave was used on every syllable without an acute or circumflex. Here the grave marked all unaccented syllables, which had lower pitch than the accented syllable. *{{lang|grc|Θὲόδὼρὸς}} {{IPA|/tʰe.ó.dɔː.ros/}}
Later on, a grave was only used to replace a final acute before another full word; the acute was kept before an enclitic or at the end of a phrase. This usage was standardized in the [[Medieval Greek|Byzantine era]], and is used in modern editions of Ancient Greek texts. Here it might mark a lowered version of a high-pitched syllable. * {{lang|grc|ἔστι τι καλόν.}} {{IPA|/és.ti.ti.ka.lón/}} ('there is something beautiful') ({{lang|grc|καλόν}} is at the end of the sentence) :: {{lang|grc|καλόν ἐστι.}} {{IPA|/ka.ló.nes.ti/}} ('it is beautiful') ({{lang|grc|ἐστι}} here is an enclitic) :: {{lang|grc|καλὸν καὶ ἀγαθόν}} {{IPA|/ka.lón.kai.a.ɡa.tʰón/}} ('good and beautiful')
==Sound changes== Greek underwent many sound changes. Some occurred between [[Proto-Indo-European language|Proto-Indo-European]] (PIE) and Proto-Greek (PGr), some between the [[Mycenaean Greek]] and Ancient Greek periods, which are separated by about 300 years (the [[Greek Dark Ages]]), and some during the Koine Greek period. Some sound changes occurred only in particular Ancient Greek dialects, not in others, and certain dialects, such as Boeotian and Laconian, underwent sound changes similar to the ones that occurred later in Koine. This section primarily describes sound changes that occurred between the Mycenaean and Ancient Greek periods and during the Ancient Greek period.
For sound changes occurring in Proto-Greek and in Koine Greek, see {{section link|Proto-Greek language|Phonology}} and [[Koine Greek phonology]].
===Debuccalization=== In Proto-Greek, the PIE sibilant {{PIE|*s}} became {{IPA|/h/}} by [[debuccalization]] in many cases.<ref name="initial s">{{Harvnb|Sihler|1995|pp=168–170|loc=§170: debuccalized initial ''s'' in Greek}}</ref> * PIE {{PIE|*so, seh₂}} > {{lang|grc|ὁ, ἡ}} {{IPA|/ho hɛː/}} ('the') ({{sm|m f}}) — compare Sanskrit ''{{transl|sa|IAST|sá sā́}}'' : PIE {{PIE|*septḿ̥}} > {{wikt-lang|grc|ἑπτά}} {{IPA|/hep.tá/}} ('seven') — compare Latin ''{{lang|la|septem}}''
Clusters of {{PIE|*s}} and a [[sonorant]] (liquid or nasal) at the beginning of a word became a voiceless resonant in some forms of Archaic Greek. Voiceless {{IPA|[r̥]}} remained in Attic at the beginning of words, and became the regular allophone of {{IPA|/r/}} in this position; voiceless {{IPA|/ʍ/}} merged with {{IPA|/h/}}; and the rest of the voiceless resonants merged with the voiced resonants.<ref>{{Harvnb|Sihler|1995|pp=170, 171|loc=§171: ''s'' in initial clusters with a sonorant}}</ref> * PIE {{PIE|*srew-}} > {{lang|grc|ῥέϝω}} > Attic {{lang|grc|ῥέω}} {{IPA|/r̥é.ɔː/}} ('flow') — compare Sanskrit ''{{transl|sa|IAST|srávanti}}'' ({{sm|3rd pl}}) ::PIE {{PIE|*sroweh₂}} > [[Corfu]] {{lang|grc|{{sc|ΡΗΟϜΑΙΣΙ}}}} {{IPA|/r̥owaisi/}} ({{sm|dat pl}}), Attic {{lang|grc|ῥοή}} {{IPA|[r̥o.ɛ̌ː]}} ('stream') * PIE {{PIE|*swe}} > Pamphylian {{lang|grc|{{sc|ϜΗΕ}}}} {{IPA|/ʍe/}}, Attic {{lang|grc|ἕ}} {{IPA|/hé/}} ({{sm|[[reflexive pronoun|refl pron]]}}) * PIE {{PIE|*slagʷ-}} > Corfu {{lang|grc|{{sc|ΛΗΑΒΩΝ}}}} {{IPA|/l̥aboːn/}}, Attic {{lang|grc|λαβών}} {{IPA|/la.bɔ̌ːn/}} ('taking') ({{sm|[[Aorist (Ancient Greek)|aor]] [[participle|ppl]]}})
PIE {{PIE|*s}} remained in clusters with stops and at the end of a word:<ref>{{Harvnb|Sihler|1995|pp=169, 170|loc=§169: unchanged ''s'' in Greek}}</ref> * PIE {{PIE|*h₁esti}} > {{lang|grc|ἐστί}} {{IPA|/es.tí/}} ('is') — compare Sanskrit ''{{transl|sa|IAST|ásti}}'', Latin ''{{lang|la|est}}'' : PIE {{PIE|*seǵʰ-s-}} > {{lang|grc|ἕξω}} {{IPA|/hék.sɔː/}} ('I will have') : PIE {{PIE|*ǵenH₁os}} > {{lang|grc|γένος}} {{IPA|/ɡénos/}} ('kind') — compare Sanskrit ''{{transl|sa|IAST|jánas}}'', Latin ''{{lang|la|genus}}''
The PIE semivowel {{PIE|*y}}, IPA {{IPA|/j/}}, was sometimes debuccalized and sometimes [[fortition|strengthened]] initially. How this development was conditioned is unclear; the involvement of the [[Laryngeal theory|laryngeals]] has been suggested. In certain other positions, it was kept, and frequently underwent other sound changes:<ref>{{Harvnb|Sihler|1995|pp=187, 188|loc=§191: ''y'' in initial position}}</ref> * PIE {{PIE|*yos, yeH₂}} > {{wikt-lang|grc|ὅς}}, {{wikt-lang|grc|ἥ}} {{IPA|[hós hɛ̌ː]}} ('who') ([[relative pronoun|{{sm|rel pron}}]]) — compare Sanskrit [[wikt:यद्#Sanskrit|''{{transl|sa|IAST|yás, yā́}}'']] * PIE [[wikt:Appendix:Proto-Indo-European/yugóm|{{PIE|*yugóm}}]] > early {{IPA|/dzu.ɡón/}} > Attic {{lang|grc|ζυγόν}} {{IPA|/sdy.ɡón/}} ('yoke') — compare Sanskrit ''{{transl|sa|IAST|yugá}}'', Latin ''{{lang|la|jugum}}'' * {{PIE|*mor-ya}} > {{lang|grc|μοῖρα}} {{IPA|/mói.ra/}} ('part') (by [[metathesis (linguistics)|metathesis]]) — compare {{lang|grc|μόρος}}
Between vowels, {{PIE|*s}} became {{IPA|/h/}}. Intervocalic {{IPA|/h/}} probably occurred in Mycenaean. In most cases it was lost by the time of Ancient Greek. In a few cases, it was [[metathesis (linguistics)|transposed]] to the beginning of the word.<ref name="Sihler intervocalic s">{{Harvnb|Sihler|1995|pp=171, 172|loc=§172: intervocalic ''s''}}</ref> Later, initial {{IPA|/h/}} was lost by [[#Psilosis|psilosis]]. * PIE [[wikt:Appendix:Proto-Indo-European/ǵénh₁os|*ǵénh₁es-os]] > PGr {{PIE|*genehos}} > Ionic {{lang|grc|γένεος}} {{IPA|/ɡé.ne.os/}} > Attic {{lang|grc|γένους}} ('of a race') {{IPA|/ɡé.nuːs/}} (contraction; {{sm|gen.}} of {{wikt-lang|grc|γένος}}) * Mycenaean ''pa-we-a₂'', possibly {{IPA|/pʰar.we.ha/}}, later {{lang|grc|φάρεα}} {{IPA|/pʰǎː.re.a/}} ('pieces of cloth') * PIE {{PIE|*(H₁)ewsoH₂}} > Proto-Greek {{PIE|*ewhō}} > {{lang|grc|εὕω}} {{IPA|/heǔ.ɔː/}} ('singe')
By [[morphological leveling]], intervocalic {{IPA|/s/}} was kept in certain noun and verb forms: for instance, the {{IPA|/s/}} marking the [[word stem|stems]] for the [[future tense|future]] and [[Aorist (Ancient Greek)|aorist tense]]s.<ref name="Sihler intervocalic s" /> *{{lang|grc|λύω, λύσω, ἔλυσα}} {{IPA|/lyý.ɔː lyý.'''s'''ɔː é.lyy.'''s'''a/}} ('I release, I will release, I released')
===Grassmann's law=== Through [[Grassmann's law]], an aspirated consonant loses its aspiration when followed by another aspirated consonant in the next syllable; this law also affects {{IPA|/h/}} resulting from debuccalization of {{PIE|*s}}; for example: * PIE {{PIE|*dʰéh₁-}} > {{lang|grc|ἔθην}} {{IPA|/é'''tʰ'''ɛːn/}} ('I placed') ({{sm|aor}}) :: {{PIE|*dʰí-dʰeh₁-}} > {{lang|grc|τίθημι}} {{IPA|/'''t'''í.tʰɛː.mi/}} ('I place') ({{sm|pres}}) :: {{PIE|*dʰé-dʰeh₁-}} > {{lang|grc|τέθηκα}} {{IPA|/'''t'''é.tʰɛː.ka/}} ('I have placed') ({{sm|perf}}) * {{PIE|*tʰrikʰ-s}} > {{wikt-lang|grc|θρίξ}} {{IPA|/'''tʰ'''ríks/}} ('hair') ({{sm|nom sg}}) :: {{PIE|*tʰrikʰ-es}} > {{lang|grc|τρίχες}} {{IPA|/'''t'''rí.kʰes/}} ('hairs') ({{sm|nom. pl}}) * PIE {{PIE|*seǵʰ-s-}} > {{lang|grc|ἕξω}} {{IPA|/'''h'''é.ksɔː/}} ('I will have') ({{sm|fut}}) :: {{PIE|*seǵʰ-}} > {{wikt-lang|grc|ἔχω}}{{IPA|/é.kʰɔː/}} ('I have') ({{sm|pres}})
===Palatalization=== In some cases, the sound {{angbr|{{lang|grc|ττ}}}} {{IPA|/tː/}} in Attic corresponds to the sound {{angbr|{{lang|grc|σσ}}}} {{IPA|/sː/}} in other dialects. These sounds developed from [[palatalization (sound change)|palatalization]] of {{lang|grc|κ, χ}},<ref>{{Harvnb|Smyth|1920|loc=[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0007:smythp=112 §112]}}</ref> and sometimes {{lang|grc|τ}}, {{lang|grc|θ}},<ref>{{Harvnb|Smyth|1920|loc=[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0007:smythp=114 §114]}}</ref> and {{lang|grc|γ}} before the pre-Greek [[semivowel]] {{IPA|/j/}}. This sound was likely pronounced as an affricate {{IPAblink|ts}} or {{IPAblink|tʃ}} earlier in the history of Greek, but inscriptions do not show the spelling {{angbr|{{lang|grc|τσ}}}}, which suggests that an affricate pronunciation did not occur in the Classical period.<ref name="Allen tt ss">{{Harvnb|Allen|1987|pp=60, 61|loc=ττ/σσ}}</ref> * *{{PIE|ēk-yōn}} > {{PIE|*ētsōn}} > {{lang|grc|ἥσσων}}, Attic {{lang|grc|ἥττων}} ('weaker') — compare {{lang|grc|ἦκα}} ('softly') * PIE {{PIE|*teh₂g-yō}} > {{PIE|*tag-yō}} > {{PIE|*tatsō}} > {{lang|grc|τάσσω}}, Attic {{lang|grc|τάττω}} ('I arrange') — compare {{lang|grc|ταγή}} ('battle line') and Latin ''{{lang|la|tangō}}'' * PIE {{PIE|*glōgʰ-yeh₂}} > {{PIE|*glokh-ya}} > {{PIE|*glōtsa}} > {{lang|grc|γλῶσσα}}, Attic {{lang|grc|γλῶττα}} ('tongue') — compare {{lang|grc|γλωχίν}} ('point')
===Loss of labiovelars=== Mycenaean Greek had three [[labialized velar consonant|labialized velar stops]] {{IPA|/kʷʰ kʷ ɡʷ/}}, aspirated, tenuis, and voiced. These derived from [[Proto-Indo-European phonology#Dorsals|PIE labiovelars]] and from sequences of a velar and {{IPA|/w/}}, and were similar to the three regular velars of Ancient Greek {{IPA|/kʰ k ɡ/}}, except with added [[labialization|lip-rounding]]. They were written all using the same symbols in [[Linear B]], and are transcribed as ''q''.<ref name="Sihler velars">{{Harvnb|Sihler|1995|loc=§154: reflexes of palatals, plain velars, and labiovelars in Greek, Italic, and Germanic}}</ref>
In Ancient Greek, all labialized velars [[Phonological change#Merger|merged]] with other stops: labials {{IPA|/pʰ p b/}}, dentals {{IPA|/tʰ t d/}}, and velars {{IPA|/kʰ k ɡ/}}. Which one they became depended on dialect and phonological environment. Because of this, certain words that originally had labialized velars have different stops depending on dialect, and certain words from the same root have different stops even in the same Ancient Greek dialect.<ref name="Sihler labiovelars">{{Harvnb|Sihler|1995|pp=160–164|loc=§161-164 A: examples of reflexes of labiovelar stops in Greek; remarks on them}}</ref> *PIE, PGr {{PIE|*kʷis, kʷid}} > Attic {{lang|grc|τίς, τί}}, Thessalian Doric {{lang|grc|κίς, κί}} ('who?, what?')<!-- May be true in all Doric. --> — compare Latin ''{{lang|la|quis, quid}}'' ::PIE, PGr {{PIE|*kʷo-yos}} > Attic {{lang|grc|ποῖος}}, Ionic {{lang|grc|κοῖος}} ('what kind?') *PIE {{PIE|*gʷʰen-yō}} > PGr {{PIE|*kʷʰenyō}} > Attic {{lang|grc|θείνω}} ('I strike') ::{{PIE|*gʷʰón-os}} > PGr {{PIE|*kʷʰónos}} > Attic {{lang|grc|φόνος}} ('slaughtering') *PIE {{PIE|kʷey(H₁)-}} ('notice') > Mycenaean ''qe-te-o'' ('paid'), Ancient Greek {{lang|grc|τίνω}} ('pay') :{{lang|grc|τιμή}} ('honor') :{{lang|grc|ποινή}} ('penalty') > Latin ''poena'')
Near {{IPA|/u uː/}} or {{IPA|/w/}}, the labialized velars had already lost their labialization in the Mycenaean period.<ref name="Sihler velars" /> *PG {{PIE|*gʷow-kʷolos}} > Mycenaean ''qo-u-ko-ro'', Ancient Greek {{lang|grc|βουκόλος}} ('cowherd') :Mycenaean ''a-pi-qo-ro'', Ancient Greek {{lang|grc|ἀμφίπολος}} ('attendant')
===Psilosis=== Through ''[[psilosis]]'' ('stripping'),<!-- Smyth doesn't use this term. --> from the term for lack of {{IPA|/h/}} ([[#Terminology|see below]]), the {{IPA|/h/}} was lost even at the beginnings of words. This sound change did not occur in Attic until the Koine period, but occurred in East Ionic and Lesbian Aeolic, and therefore can be seen in certain Homeric forms.<ref>{{Harvnb|Smyth|loc=§9 D: footnote on loss of rough breathing}}</ref> These dialects are called ''psilotic''.<ref name="initial s" /> * Homeric {{lang|grc|ἠέλιος}} {{IPA|/ɛɛ.é.li.os/}}, Attic {{lang|grc|ἥλιος}} {{IPA|/hɛɛ́.li.os/}} '(sun') * Homeric {{lang|grc|ἠώς}} {{IPA|/ɛɛ.ɔɔ́s/}}, Attic {{lang|grc|ἑώς}} {{IPA|/he(.)ɔɔ́s/}} ('dawn') * Homeric {{lang|grc|οὖρος}} {{IPA|[óo.ros]}}, Attic {{lang|grc|ὅρος}} {{IPA|/hó.ros/}} ('border')
Even later, during the Koine Greek period, {{IPA|/h/}} disappeared totally from Greek and never reappeared, resulting in Modern Greek not possessing this phoneme at all.
===Spirantization=== The Classical Greek aspirated and voiced stops changed to voiceless and voiced [[fricative consonant|fricatives]] during the period of Koine Greek (spirantization, a form of [[lenition]]).
Spirantization of {{IPA|/tʰ/}} occurred earlier in Laconian Greek. Some examples are transcribed by [[Aristophanes]] and [[Thucydides]], such as {{lang|grc|ναὶ τὼ σιώ}} for {{lang|grc|ναὶ τὼ θεώ}} ('Yes, by the two gods!') and {{lang|grc|παρσένε σιά}} for {{lang|grc|παρθένε θεά}} ("virgin goddess!') (''[[Lysistrata]]'' 142 and 1263), {{lang|grc|σύματος}} for {{lang|grc|θύματος}} ('sacrificial victim') (''[[History of the Peloponnesian War|Histories]]'' book 5, chapter 77).<ref>{{LSJ|parse/nos|παρσένος}}, {{LSJ|sia/|σιά}}, {{LSJ|siw/2|σιώ}}, {{LSJ|su{{=}}ma|σῦμα|ref}}</ref> These spellings indicate that {{IPA|/tʰ/}} was pronounced as a dental fricative {{IPAblink|θ}} or a sibilant {{IPA|[s]}}, the same change that occurred later in Koine. Greek spelling, however, does not have a letter for a labial or velar fricative, so it is impossible to tell whether {{IPA|/pʰ kʰ/}} also changed to {{IPA|/f x/}}.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1987|pp=23–26|loc=development of aspirated stops to fricatives}}</ref>
===Compensatory lengthening=== In Attic, Ionic, and Doric, vowels were usually lengthened when a following consonant was lost. The syllable before the consonant was originally heavy, but loss of the consonant would cause it to be light. Therefore, the vowel before the consonant was lengthened, so that the syllable would continue to be heavy. This sound change is called compensatory lengthening, because the vowel length compensates for the loss of the consonant. The result of lengthening depended on dialect and time period. ===Contraction=== In Attic, some cases of long vowels arose through [[contraction (grammar)|contraction]] of adjacent short vowels where a consonant had been lost between them. {{angbr|{{lang|grc|ει}}}} {{IPA|/eː/}} came from contraction of {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|εε}}}} and {{angbr|{{lang|grc|ου}}}} {{IPA|/oː/}} through contraction of {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|εο}}}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|οε}}}}, or {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|oo}}}}. {{angbr|{{lang|grc|ω}}}} {{IPA|/ɔː/}} arose from {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|αο}}}} and {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|οα}}}}, {{angbr|{{lang|grc|η}}}} {{IPA|/ɛː/}} from {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|εα}}}}, and {{angbr|{{lang|grc|ᾱ}}}} {{IPA|/aː/}} from {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|αε}}}} and {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|αα}}}}. Contractions involving diphthongs ending in {{IPA|/i̯/}} resulted in the long diphthongs {{IPA|/ɛːi̯ aːi̯ ɔːi̯/}}.
Uncontracted forms are found in other dialects, such as in Ionic.
===Monophthongization=== The diphthongs {{IPA|/ei ou/}} became the long [[monophthong]]s {{IPA|/eː/}} and {{IPA|/oː/}} before the Classical period.
===Vowel raising and fronting=== In Archaic Greek, upsilon {{angbr|{{lang|grc|{{sc|Υ}}}}}} represented the [[close back rounded vowel|back vowel]] {{IPA|/u uː/}}. In Attic and Ionic, this vowel was [[fronting (phonology)|fronted]] around the 6th or 7th century BC. It likely first became [[close central rounded vowel|central]] {{IPA|[ʉ ʉː]}}, and then the [[close front rounded vowel|front]] {{IPA|[y yː]}}.<ref name="Allen u" />
During the Classical period, {{IPA|/oː/}} was raised to {{IPA|[uː]}}, and thus took up the empty space of the earlier {{IPA|/uː/}} phoneme. The fact that {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|υ}}}} was never confused with {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ου}}}} indicates that {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|υ}}}} was fronted before {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ου}}}} was raised.
In early Koine Greek, {{IPA|/eː/}} was raised and merged with original {{IPA|/iː/}}.
===Attic–Ionic vowel shift=== In Attic and Ionic, the Proto-Greek long {{IPA|/aː/}} shifted to {{IPA|/ɛː/}}. This shift did not happen in the other dialects. Thus, some cases of Attic and Ionic {{lang|grc|η}} correspond to Doric and Aeolic {{lang|grc|ᾱ}}, and other cases correspond to Doric and Aeolic {{lang|grc|η}}.<ref>{{Harvnb|Smyth|1920|loc=§30, 30 D: Attic {{lang|grc|η ᾱ}}; footnote on Doric, Aeolic, and Ionic}}</ref> *Doric and Aeolic {{lang|grc|μᾱ́τηρ}}, Attic and Ionic {{lang|grc|μήτηρ}} {{IPA|[mǎː.tɛːr mɛ̌ːtɛːr]}} ('mother') — compare Latin ''{{lang|la|māter}}''
The vowel first shifted to {{IPA|/æː/}}, at which point it was distinct from Proto-Greek long {{IPA|/eː/}}, and then later {{IPA|/æː/}} and {{IPA|/eː/}} merged as {{IPA|/ɛː/}}. This is indicated by inscriptions in the [[Cyclades]], which write Proto-Greek {{IPA|/eː/}} as {{angbr|{{lang|grc|{{sc|Ε}}}}}}, but the shifted {{IPA|/æː/}} as {{angbr|{{lang|grc|{{sc|Η}}}}}} and new {{IPA|/aː/}} from compensatory lengthening as {{angbr|{{lang|grc|{{sc|Α}}}}}}.<ref name="Sihler Attic-Ionic" />
In Attic, both {{IPA|/æː/}} and Proto-Greek {{IPA|/eː/}} were written as {{angbr|{{lang|grc|{{sc|Η}}}}}}, but they merged to {{IPA|/ɛː/}} at the end of the 5th century BC. At this point, nouns in the [[Ancient Greek nouns#Masculine a-stem|masculine first declension]] were confused with [[Ancient Greek nouns#S-stems|third-declension nouns with stems in {{IPA|/es/}}]]. The first-declension nouns had {{IPA|/ɛː/}} resulting from original {{IPA|/aː/}}, while the third-declension nouns had {{IPA|/ɛː/}} resulting from contraction of {{IPA|/ea/}}.<ref name="Sihler Attic-Ionic" /> * {{lang|grc|Αἰσχίνης}} [[Aeschines]] ({{sm|1st decl}}) : {{lang|grc|Αἰσχίνου}} ({{sm|gen sg}}) :: incorrect {{sm|3rd decl gen sg}} {{lang|grc|Αἰσχίνους}} : {{lang|grc|Αἰσχίνην}} ({{sm|acc sg}}) * {{lang|grc|Ἰπποκράτης}} [[Hippocrates]] ({{sm|3rd decl}}) : {{lang|grc|Ἱπποκράτους}} ({{sm|gen sg}}) : {{lang|grc|Ἱπποκράτη}} ({{sm|acc sg}}) :: incorrect {{sm|1st decl acc sg}} {{lang|grc|Ἱπποκράτην}}
In addition, words that had original {{lang|grc|η}} in both Attic and Doric were given false Doric forms with {{lang|grc|ᾱ}} in the choral passages of Athenian plays, indicating that Athenians could not distinguish the Attic-Ionic shifted {{lang|grc|ᾱ}} from original Proto-Greek {{lang|grc|η}}.<ref name="Sihler Attic-Ionic" /> * Attic and Doric {{lang|grc|πηδός}} ('blade of an oar') : incorrect Doric form {{lang|grc|πᾱδός}}
In Attic, {{IPA|/aː/}} rather than {{IPA|/εː/}} is found immediately after {{IPA|/e i r/}}, except in certain cases where the sound {{lang|grc|ϝ}} {{IPA|/w/}} formerly came between the {{IPA|/e i r/}} and the {{IPA|/aː/}} ([[#Semivowels|see above]]).<ref name="Sihler Attic-Ionic" /> * Doric {{lang|grc|ᾱ̔μέρᾱ}}, Attic {{lang|grc|ἡμέρᾱ}}, Ionic {{lang|grc|ἡμέρη}} {{IPA|/haː.mé.raː hɛː.mé.raː hɛː.mé.rɛː/}} ('day') * Attic {{lang|grc|οἵᾱ}}, Ionic {{lang|grc|οἵη}} {{IPA|[hoǰ.jaː hoǰ.jɛː]}} ('such as') ({{sm|fem nom sg}}) * Attic {{lang|grc|νέᾱ}}, Ionic {{lang|grc|νέη}} {{IPA|/né.aː né.ɛː/}} ('new') ({{sm|fem nom sg}}) < {{lang|grc|νέϝος}} * But Attic {{lang|grc|κόρη}}, Ionic {{lang|grc|κούρη}}, Doric {{lang|grc|κόρᾱ}} and {{lang|grc|κώρᾱ}} ('young girl') < {{lang|grc|κόρϝᾱ}} (as also in Arcadocypriot)
The fact that {{IPA|/aː/}} is found instead of {{IPA|/εː/}} may indicate that earlier, the vowel shifted to {{IPA|/ɛː/}} in all cases, but then shifted back to {{IPA|/aː/}} after {{IPA|/e i r/}} (reversion), or that the vowel never shifted at all in these cases. Sihler says that Attic {{IPA|/aː/}} is from reversion.<ref name="Sihler Attic-Ionic" />
This shift did not affect cases of long {{IPA|/aː/}} that developed from the contraction of certain sequences of vowels that contain {{lang|grc|α}}. Thus, the vowels {{IPA|/aː/}} and {{IPA|/aːi̯/}} are common in verbs with ''a''-contracted present and imperfect forms, such as {{wikt-lang|grc|ὁράω}} "see". The examples below are shown with the hypothetical original forms from which they were contracted. * infinitive: {{lang|grc|ὁρᾶν}} {{IPA|/ho.râːn/}} "to see" < {{lang|grc|*ὁράεεν}} {{IPA|/ho.rá.e.en/}} * third person singular present indicative active: {{lang|grc|ὁρᾷ}} {{IPA|/ho.râːi̯/}} "he sees" < {{lang|grc|*ὁράει}} {{IPA|*/ho.rá.ei/}} * third person singular imperfect indicative active: {{lang|grc|ὥρᾱ}} {{IPA|/hɔ̌ː.raː/}} "he saw" < {{lang|grc|*ὥραε}} {{IPA|*/hǒː.ra.e/}}
Also unaffected was long {{IPA|/aː/}} that arose by [[#Compensatory lengthening|compensatory lengthening]] of short {{IPA|/a/}}. Thus, Attic and Ionic had a contrast between the feminine genitive singular {{lang|grc|ταύτης}} {{IPA|/taú.tɛːs/}} and feminine accusative plural {{lang|grc|ταύτᾱς}} {{IPA|/taú.taːs/}}, forms of the adjective and pronoun {{lang|grc|οὗτος}} "this, that". The first derived from an original ''*tautās'' with shifting of ''ā'' to ''ē'', the other from ''*tautans'' with compensatory lengthening of ''ans'' to ''ās''.
===Assimilation=== When one consonant comes next to another in verb or noun conjugation or word derivation, various [[sandhi]] rules apply. When these rules affect the forms of nouns and adjectives or of compound words, they are reflected in spelling. Between words, the same rules also applied, but they are not reflected in standard spelling, only in inscriptions.
Rules: * '''Most basic rule''': When two sounds appear next to each other, the first [[Assimilation (linguistics)|assimilates]] in voicing and aspiration to the second. ** This applies fully to stops. Fricatives assimilate only in voicing, sonorants do not assimilate. * Before an {{IPA|/s/}} (future, aorist stem), velars become {{IPA|[k]}}, labials become {{IPA|[p]}}, and dentals disappear. * Before a {{IPA|/tʰ/}} (aorist passive stem), velars become {{IPA|[kʰ]}}, labials become {{IPA|[pʰ]}}, and dentals become {{IPA|[s]}}. * Before an {{IPA|/m/}} (perfect middle first-singular, first-plural, participle), velars become {{IPA|[ɡ]}}, nasal+velar becomes {{IPA|[ɡ]}}, labials become {{IPA|[m]}}, dentals become {{IPA|[s]}}, other sonorants remain the same.

The alveolar nasal {{IPA|/n/}} assimilates in [[place of articulation]], changing to a labial or velar nasal before labials or velars: * {{lang|grc|μ}} {{IPA|[m]}} before the labials {{IPA|/b/}}, {{IPA|/p/}}, {{IPA|/pʰ/}}, {{IPA|/m/}} (and the cluster {{IPA|/ps/}}): : {{lang|grc|ἐν- + βαίνω > ἐμβαίνω; ἐν- + πάθεια > ἐμπάθεια; ἐν- + φαίνω > ἐμφαίνω; ἐν- + μένω > ἐμμένω; ἐν- + ψυχή + -ος > ἔμψυχος}}; * {{lang|grc|γ}} {{IPA|[ŋ]}} before the velars {{IPA|/ɡ/}}, {{IPA|/k/}}, {{IPA|/kʰ/}} (and the cluster {{IPA|/ks/}}): : {{lang|grc|ἐν- + γίγνομαι > ἐγγίγνομαι; ἐν- + καλέω > ἐγκαλέω; ἐν- + χέω > ἐγχέω; συν- + ξηραίνω > συγξηραίνω}}
When {{IPA|/n/}} precedes {{IPA|/l/}}, the first consonant assimilates to the second, [[gemination]] takes place, and the combination is pronounced {{IPA|[lː]}}, as in {{angbr|{{lang|grc|συλλαμβάνω}}}} from [[underlying representation|underlying]] {{lang|grc|*συνλαμβάνω}}.
The sound of zeta {{angbr|{{lang|grc|ζ}}}} develops from original {{PIE|*sd}} in some cases, and in other cases from {{PIE|*y dy gy}}. In the second case, it was likely first pronounced {{IPAblink|dʒ}} or {{IPAblink|dz}}, and this cluster underwent [[metathesis (linguistics)|metathesis]] early in the Ancient Greek period. Metathesis is likely in this case; clusters of a voiced stop and {{IPA|/s/}}, like {{IPA|/bs gs/}}, do not occur in Ancient Greek, since they change to {{IPA|/ps ks/}} by assimilation ([[#Assimilation|see below]]), while clusters with the opposite order, like {{IPA|/sb sɡ/}}, pronounced {{IPA|[zd zɡ]}}, do occur.<ref name="Allen z" /> *{{lang|grc|Ἀθήναζε}} ('to Athens') < {{lang|grc|Ἀθήνᾱσ-δε}} *{{lang|grc|ἵζω}} ('set') < Proto-Indo-European {{PIE|*si-sdō}} (Latin {{lang|la|sīdō}}: [[reduplication#Indo-European|reduplicated present]]), from [[Indo-European ablaut|zero-grade]] of the root of {{lang|grc|ἕδος}} < {{PIE|*sedos}} "seat" *{{lang|grc|πεζός}} ('on foot') < PGr {{PIE|*ped-yos}}, from the root of {{lang|grc|πούς, ποδός}} "foot" *{{lang|grc|ἅζομαι}} ('revere') < PGr {{PIE|*hag-yomai}}, from the root of {{lang|grc|ἅγ-ιος}} ('holy')
==Terminology== Ancient grammarians, such as Aristotle in his ''[[Poetics (Aristotle)|Poetics]]'' and [[Dionysius Thrax]] in his [[Art of Grammar]], categorized letters ({{LSJ|gra/mma|γράμματα}}) according to what speech sounds ({{LSJ|stoixei{{=}}on|στοιχεῖα}} 'elements') they represented. They called the letters for vowels {{LSJ|fwnh/eis|φωνήεντα}} ('pronounceable', singular {{lang|grc|φωνῆεν}}); the letters for the nasals, liquids, and {{IPA|/s/}}, and the letters for the consonant clusters {{IPA|/ps ks sd/}}, {{LSJ|h(mi/fwnos|ἡμίφωνα}} ('half-voiced', singular {{lang|grc|ἡμίφωνον}}); and the letters for the stops {{LSJ|a)/fwnos|ἄφωνα}} ('voiceless', singular {{lang|grc|ἄφωνον}}).<ref>{{Harvnb|Aristotle|loc=1456b}}</ref> Dionysius also called consonants in general {{LSJ|su/mfwnos|σύμφωνα}} ('pronounced with [a vowel]', {{lang|grc|σύμφωνον}}).<ref>{{Harvnb|Dionysius|loc=§6}}</ref>
All the Greek terms for letters or sounds are [[nominalization|nominalized]] adjectives in the [[grammatical gender|neuter gender]], to agree with the neuter nouns {{lang|grc|στοιχεῖον}} and {{lang|grc|γράμμα}}, since they were used to modify the nouns, as in {{lang|grc|φωνῆεν στοιχεῖον}} ('pronounceable element') or {{lang|grc|ἄφωνα γράμματα}} ('unpronounceable letters'). Many also use the root of the [[deverbal noun]] {{LSJ|fwnh/|φωνή}} ('voice, sound').
The words {{lang|grc|φωνῆεν, σύμφωνον, ἡμίφωνον, ἄφωνον}} were [[calque|loan-translated]] into Latin as ''{{lang|la|vōcālis, cōnsōnāns, semivocālis, mūta}}''. The Latin words are feminine because the Latin noun ''{{lang|la|littera}}'' ('letter') is feminine. They were later [[loanword|borrowed]] into English as ''vowel'', ''consonant'', ''semivowel'', ''mute''.
The categories of vowel letters were {{lang|grc|δίχρονα, βραχέα, μακρά}} ('two-time, short, long'). These adjectives describe whether the vowel letters represented both long and short vowels, only short vowels or only long vowels. Additionally, vowels that ordinarily functioned as the first and second elements of diphthongs were called {{lang|grc|προτακτικά}} ('prefixable') and {{lang|grc|ὑποτακτικά}} ('suffixable'). The category of {{lang|grc|δίφθογγοι}} included both diphthongs and the [[spurious diphthong]]s {{lang|grc|ει ου}}, which were pronounced as long vowels in the Classical period.
The categories {{lang|grc|ἡμίφωνα}} and {{lang|grc|ἄφωνα}} roughly correspond to the modern terms ''continuant''<!-- Allen says so unreservedly, but "continuant" does not include nasals in modern phonological theory: see Distinctive feature. --> and ''stop''. Greek grammarians placed the letters {{angbr|{{lang|grc|β δ γ φ θ χ}}}} in the category of stops, not of continuants, indicating that they represented stops in Ancient Greek, rather than fricatives, as in Modern Greek.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1987|p=19|loc=Ancient Greek terminology for consonants}}</ref>
Stops were divided into three categories using the adjectives {{lang|grc|δασέα}} ('thick'), {{lang|grc|ψιλά}} ('thin'), and {{lang|grc|μέσα}} ('middle'), as shown in the table below. The first two terms indicate a [[binary opposition]] typical of Greek thought: they referred to stops with and without [[aspirated consonant|aspiration]]. The voiced stops did not fit in either category and so they were called "middle". The concepts of [[voice (phonetics)|voice]] and [[voicelessness]] (presence or absence of vibration of the [[vocal folds]]) were unknown to the Greeks and were not developed in the Western grammatical tradition until the 19th century, when the [[Shiksha|Sanskrit grammatical tradition]] began to be studied by Westerners.<ref name="Allen voiced plosives" />
The glottal fricative {{IPA|/h/}} was originally called {{lang|grc|πνεῦμα}} ('breath'), and it was classified as a {{lang|grc|προσῳδία}}, the category to which the acute, grave, and circumflex accents also belong. Later, a diacritic for the sound was created, and it was called [[pleonasm|pleonastically]] {{lang|grc|πνεῦμα δασύ}} ('rough breathing'). Finally, a diacritic representing the absence of {{IPA|/h/}} was created, and it was called {{lang|grc|πνεῦμα ψιλόν}} ('smooth breathing').<ref name="Allen h" /> The diacritics were also called {{lang|grc|προσῳδία δασεῖα}} and {{lang|grc|προσῳδία ψιλή}} ('thick accent' and 'thin accent'), from which come the Modern Greek nouns {{lang|el|δασεία}} and {{lang|el|ψιλή}}.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}}

==Reconstruction== The above information is based on a large body of evidence which was discussed extensively by linguists and philologists of the 19th and 20th centuries. The following section provides a short summary of the kinds of evidence and arguments that have been used in this debate, and gives some hints as to the sources of uncertainty that still prevails with respect to some details.
===Internal evidence===
====Evidence from spelling==== Whenever a new set of written symbols, such as an alphabet, is created for a language, the written symbols typically correspond to the spoken sounds, and the spelling or orthography is therefore [[phonemic orthography|phonemic]] or ''[[orthographic depth|transparent]]'': it is easy to pronounce a word by seeing how it is spelled, and conversely to spell a word by knowing how it is pronounced. Until the pronunciation of the language changes, spelling mistakes do not occur, since spelling and pronunciation match each other.
When the pronunciation changes, there are two options. The first is [[spelling reform]]: the spelling of words is changed to reflect the new pronunciation. In this case, the date of a spelling reform generally indicates the approximate time when the pronunciation changed.
The second option is that the spelling remains the same, while the pronunciation changes. In this case, the spelling system is called ''conservative'' or ''historical'', since it reflects the pronunciation at an earlier period in the language. It is also called ''opaque'', because there is not a simple correspondence between written symbols and spoken sounds: it is more difficult to pronounce a word by seeing its spelling, and conversely to spell a word by knowing how to pronounce it.
In a language with a historical spelling system, spelling mistakes indicate change in pronunciation. Writers with incomplete knowledge of the spelling system will misspell words, and in general their misspellings reflect the way they pronounced the words.
* If scribes very often confuse two letters, this implies that the sounds denoted by the two letters were the same: that the sounds have merged. This happened early with {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ι ει}}}}. A little later, it happened with {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|υ οι}}}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ο ω}}}}, and {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ε αι}}}}. Later still, {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|η}}}} was confused with the already merged {{angbr|{{lang|grc|ι ει}}}}. * If scribes omit a letter where it would usually be written, or insert it where it does not belong ([[hypercorrection]]), this implies that the sound that the letter represented had been lost in speech. This happened early with word-initial rough breathing ({{IPA|/h/}}) in most forms of Greek. Another example is the occasional omission of the iota subscript of long diphthongs (see above).
Spelling mistakes provide limited evidence: they only indicate the pronunciation of the scribe who made the spelling mistake, not the pronunciation of all speakers of the language at the time. Ancient Greek was a language with many regional variants and social registers. Many of the pronunciation changes of Koine Greek probably occurred earlier in some regional pronunciations and [[sociolect]]s of Attic even in the Classical Age, but the older pronunciations were preserved in more learned speech.
====Onomatopoeic words==== Greek literature sometimes contains representations of animal cries in Greek letters. The most often quoted example is {{lang|grc|βῆ βῆ}}, used to render the cry of sheep, and is used as evidence that beta had a voiced bilabial plosive pronunciation and eta was a long open-mid front vowel. [[Onomatopoeia|Onomatopoeic]] verbs such as {{lang|grc|μυκάομαι}} for the lowing of cattle (cf. Latin ''{{lang|la|mugire}}''), {{lang|grc|βρυχάομαι}} for the roaring of lions (cf. Latin ''{{lang|la|rugire}}'') and {{lang|grc|κόκκυξ}} as the name of the cuckoo (cf. Latin ''{{lang|la|cuculus}}'') suggest an archaic {{IPA|[uː]}} pronunciation of long upsilon, before this vowel was fronted to {{IPA|[yː]}}.
====Morpho-phonological facts==== Sounds undergo regular changes, such as assimilation or dissimilation, in certain environments within words, which are sometimes indicated in writing. These can be used to reconstruct the nature of the sounds involved. * <{{lang|grc|π,τ,κ}}> at the end of some words are regularly changed to <{{lang|grc|φ,θ,χ}}> when preceding a rough breathing in the next word. Thus, e.g.: {{lang|grc|ἐφ' ἁλός}} for {{lang|grc|ἐπὶ ἁλός}} or {{lang|grc|καθ' ἡμᾶς}} for {{lang|grc|κατὰ ἡμᾶς}}. * <{{lang|grc|π,τ,κ}}> at the end of the first member of composite words are regularly changed to <{{lang|grc|φ,θ,χ}}> when preceding a ''spiritus asper'' in the next member of the composite word. Thus e.g.: {{lang|grc|ἔφιππος, καθάπτω}} * The Attic dialect in particular is marked by contractions: two vowels without an intervening consonant were merged in a single syllable; for instance uncontracted (disyllabic) {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|εα}}}} ({{IPA|[e.a]}}) occurs regularly in dialects but contracts to {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|η}}}} in Attic, supporting the view that {{lang|grc|η}} was pronounced {{IPA|[ɛː]}} (intermediate between {{IPA|[e]}} and {{IPA|[a]}}) rather than {{IPA|[i]}} as in Modern Greek. Similarly, uncontracted {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|εε}}}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|οο}}}} ({{IPA|[e.e], [o.o]}}) occur regularly in Ionic but contract to {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ει}}}} and {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ου}}}} in Attic, suggesting {{IPA|[eː], [oː]}} values for the spurious diphthongs {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ει}}}} and {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ου}}}} in Attic as opposed to the [i] and [u] sounds they later acquired.
====Non-standard spellings==== Morphophonological alternations like the above are often treated differently in non-standard spellings than in standardised literary spelling. This may lead to doubts about the representativeness of the literary dialect and may in some cases force slightly different reconstructions than if one were only to take the literary texts of the high standard language into account. Thus, e.g.:
*non-standard epigraphical spelling sometimes indicates assimilation of final {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|κ}}}} to {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|γ}}}} before voiced consonants in a following word, or of final {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|κ}}}} to {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|χ}}}} before aspirated sounds, in words like {{lang|grc|ἐκ}}.
====Metrical evidence==== The metres used in Classical Greek poetry are based on the patterns of light and heavy syllables, and can thus sometimes provide evidence as to the length of vowels where this is not evident from the orthography. By the 4th century AD poetry was normally written using stress-based metres, suggesting that the distinctions between long and short vowels had been lost by then, and the pitch accent had been replaced by a stress accent.
===External evidence===
====Orthoepic descriptions==== Some ancient grammarians attempt to give systematic descriptions of the sounds of the language. In other authors one can sometimes find occasional remarks about correct pronunciation of certain sounds. However, both types of evidence are often difficult to interpret, because the phonetic terminology of the time was often vague, and it is often not clear in what relation the described forms of the language stand to those which were actually spoken by different groups of the population.
Important ancient authors include:
* [[Dionysius Thrax]] * [[Dionysius of Halicarnassus]] * [[Aelius Herodianus]]
====Cross-dialectal comparison==== Sometimes the comparison of standard Attic Greek with the written forms of other [[Ancient Greek dialects|Greek dialects]], or the humorous renderings of dialectal speech in Attic theatrical works, can provide hints as to the phonetic value of certain spellings. An example of this treatment with Spartan Greek is given [[#Fricatives|above]].
====Loanwords==== The spelling of Greek [[loanword]]s in other languages and [[vice versa]] can provide important hints about pronunciation. However, the evidence is often difficult to interpret or indecisive. The sounds of loanwords are often not taken over identically into the receiving language. Where the receiving language lacks a sound that corresponds exactly to that of the source language, sounds are usually mapped to some other, similar sound.
In this regard, Latin is of great value to the reconstruction of ancient Greek phonology because of its close proximity to the Greek world which caused numerous Greek words to be borrowed by the Romans. At first, Greek loanwords denoting technical terms or proper names which contained the letter {{lang|grc|Φ}} were imported in Latin with the spelling ''{{lang|la|P}}'' or ''{{lang|la|PH}}'', indicating an effort to imitate, albeit imperfectly, a sound that Latin lacked. Later on, in the 1st centuries AD, spellings with ''{{lang|la|F}}'' start to appear in such loanwords, signaling the onset of the fricative pronunciation of {{lang|grc|Φ}}. Thus, in the 2nd century AD, ''{{lang|la|Filippus}}'' replaces ''{{lang|la|P(h)ilippus}}''. At about the same time, the letter ''{{lang|la|F}}'' also begins to be used as a substitute for the letter {{lang|grc|Θ}}, for lack of a better choice, indicating that the sound of Greek theta had become a fricative as well.
For the purpose of borrowing certain other Greek words, the Romans added the letters ''{{lang|la|Y}}'' and ''{{lang|la|Z}}'' to the Latin alphabet, taken directly from the Greek one. These additions are important as they show that the Romans had no symbols to represent the sounds of the letters {{lang|grc|Υ}} and {{lang|grc|Ζ}} in Greek, which means that in these cases no known sound of Latin can be used to reconstruct the Greek sounds.
Latin often wrote {{angbr|{{lang|la|i u}}}} for Greek {{angbr|{{lang|grc|ε ο}}}}. This can be explained by the fact that Latin {{IPA|/i u/}} were pronounced as near-close {{IPA|[ɪ ʊ]}}, and therefore were as similar to the Ancient Greek mid vowels {{IPA|/e o/}} as to the Ancient Greek close vowels {{IPA|/i u/}}.<ref name="Allen short mid" /> *{{lang|grc|Φιλουμένη}} > ''{{lang|la|Philumina}}'' *{{lang|grc|ἐμπόριον}} > ''{{lang|la|empurium}}''
Sanskrit, Persian, and Armenian also provide evidence.
The quality of short {{IPA|/a/}} is shown by some transcriptions between Ancient Greek and Sanskrit. Greek short {{IPA|/a/}} was transcribed with Sanskrit long {{transl|sa|IAST|ā}}, not with Sanskrit short {{transl|sa|IAST|a}}, which had a closer pronunciation: {{IPA|[ə]}}. Conversely, Sanskrit short {{transl|sa|IAST|a}} was transcribed with Greek {{lang|grc|ε}}.<ref name="Allen a" /> * Gr {{lang|grc|ἀπόκλιμα}} {{IPA|[apóklima]}} > Skt {{transl|sa|IAST|āpoklima-}} {{IPA|[aːpoːklimə]}} (an [[astrology|astrological]] term) * Skt {{transl|sa|IAST|brāhmaṇa-}} {{IPA|[bɽaːɦməɳə]}} > Gr {{lang|grc|{{sc|ΒΡΑΜΕΝΑΙ}}}}
====Comparison with older alphabets==== The Greek alphabet developed from the older [[Phoenician alphabet]]. It may be assumed that the Greeks tended to assign to each Phoenician letter that Greek sound which most closely resembled the Phoenician sound. But, as with loanwords, the interpretation is not straightforward.
====Comparison with younger/derived alphabets==== The Greek alphabet was in turn the basis of other alphabets, notably the [[Etruscan alphabet|Etruscan]] and [[Coptic alphabet|Coptic]] and later the [[Armenian alphabet|Armenian]], [[Gothic alphabet|Gothic]], and [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]]. Similar arguments can be derived in these cases as in the Phoenician-Greek case.
For example, in Cyrillic, the letter [[ve (Cyrillic)|{{script|Cyrs|В}}]] (''ve'') stands for {{IPA|[v]}}, confirming that beta was pronounced as a fricative by the 9th century AD, while the new letter [[be (Cyrillic)|{{script|Cyrs|Б}}]] (''be'') was invented to note the sound {{IPA|[b]}}. Conversely, in Gothic, the letter derived from beta stands for {{IPA|[b]}}, so in the 4th century AD, beta may have still been a plosive in Greek although according to evidence from the Greek papyri of Egypt, beta as a stop had been generally replaced by beta as a voiced bilabial fricative {{IPA|[β]}} by the first century AD.
====Comparison with Modern Greek==== Any reconstruction of Ancient Greek needs to take into account how the sounds later developed towards Modern Greek, and how these changes could have occurred. In general, the changes between the reconstructed Ancient Greek and Modern Greek are assumed to be unproblematic in this respect by historical linguists, because all the relevant changes ([[spirantization]], chain-shifts of long vowels towards {{IPA|[i]}}, loss of initial {{IPA|[h]}}, restructuring of vowel-length and accentuation systems, etc.) are of types that are cross-linguistically frequently attested and relatively easy to explain.
====Comparative reconstruction of Indo-European==== Systematic relationships between sounds in Greek and sounds in other Indo-European languages are taken as strong evidence for reconstruction by historical linguists, because such relationships indicate that these sounds may go back to an inherited sound in the proto-language.
==History of the reconstruction of ancient pronunciation==
===The Renaissance=== Until the 15th century (during the time of the Byzantine Greek Empire) ancient Greek texts were pronounced exactly like contemporary Greek when they were read aloud. From about 1486, various scholars (notably [[Antonio of Lebrixa]], [[Girolamo Aleandro]], and [[Aldus Manutius]]) judged that this pronunciation appeared to be inconsistent with the descriptions handed down by ancient grammarians, and suggested alternative pronunciations.
[[Johann Reuchlin]], the leading Greek scholar in the West around 1500, had taken his Greek learning from Byzantine émigré scholars, and continued to use the modern pronunciation.<!-- need to check up on attribution of Reuchlin source --> This pronunciation system was called into question by [[Desiderius Erasmus]] (1466–1536) who in 1528 published ''{{lang|la|De recta Latini Graecique sermonis pronuntiatione dialogus}}'', a philological treatise clothed in the form of a philosophical dialogue, in which he developed the idea of a historical reconstruction of ancient Latin and Greek pronunciation. The two models of pronunciation became soon known, after their principal proponents, as the "[[Reuchlinian pronunciation|Reuchlinian]]" and the "[[Erasmian pronunciation|Erasmian]]" system, or, after the characteristic vowel pronunciations, as the "[[Iotacism|iotacist]]" (or "itacist" ) and the "etacist" system, respectively.
Erasmus' reconstruction was based on a wide range of arguments, derived from the philological knowledge available at his time. In the main, he strove for a more regular correspondence of letters to sounds, assuming that different letters must have stood for different sounds, and same letters for same sounds. That led him, for instance, to posit that the various letters which in the iotacist system all denoted {{IPA|[i]}} must have had different values, and that {{lang|grc|ει}}, {{lang|grc|αι}}, {{lang|grc|οι}}, {{lang|grc|ευ}}, {{lang|grc|αυ}}, {{lang|grc|ου}} were all diphthongs with a closing offglide. He also insisted on taking the accounts of ancient grammarians literally, for instance where they described vowels as being distinctively long and short, or the acute and circumflex accents as being clearly distinguished by pitch contours. In addition, he drew on evidence from word correspondences between Greek and Latin as well as some other European languages. Some of his arguments in this direction are, in hindsight, mistaken, because he naturally lacked much of the knowledge developed through later linguistic work. Thus, he could not distinguish between Latin-Greek word relations based on loans (e.g. {{lang|grc|Φοῖβος}} — ''{{lang|la|Phoebus}}'') on the one hand, and those based on common descent from [[Indo-European languages|Indo-European]] (e.g. {{lang|grc|φῶρ}} — ''{{lang|la|fūr}}'') on the other. He also fell victim to a few spurious relations due to mere accidental similarity (e.g. Greek {{lang|grc|θύειν}} 'to sacrifice' — French ''{{lang|fr|tuer}}'', 'to kill'). In other areas, his arguments are of quite the same kind as those used by modern linguistics, e.g. where he argues on the basis of cross-dialectal correspondences within Greek that {{lang|grc|η}} must have been a rather open ''e''-sound, close to {{IPA|[a]}}.
Erasmus also took great pains to assign to the members in his reconstructed system plausible phonetic values. This was no easy task, as contemporary grammatical theory lacked the rich and precise terminology to describe such values. In order to overcome that problem, Erasmus drew upon his knowledge of the sound repertoires of contemporary living languages, for instance likening his reconstructed {{lang|grc|η}} to Scots ''a'' ({{IPA|[æ]}}), his reconstructed {{lang|grc|ου}} to Dutch ''{{lang|nl|ou}}'' ({{IPA|[oʊ]}}), and his reconstructed {{lang|grc|οι}} to French ''{{lang|fr|oi}}'' (at that time pronounced {{IPA|[oɪ]}}).
Erasmus assigned to the Greek consonant letters {{lang|grc|β}}, {{lang|grc|γ}}, {{lang|grc|δ}} the sounds of voiced plosives {{IPA|/b/}}, {{IPA|/ɡ/}}, {{IPA|/d/}}, while for the consonant letters {{lang|grc|φ}}, {{lang|grc|θ}}, and {{lang|grc|χ}} he advocated the use of fricatives {{IPA|/f/}}, {{IPA|/θ/}}, {{IPA|/x/}} as in Modern Greek (arguing, however, that this type of {{IPA|/f/}} must have been different from that denoted by Latin {{angle bracket|f}}).
The reception of Erasmus' idea among his contemporaries was mixed. Most prominent among those scholars who resisted his move was [[Philipp Melanchthon]], a student of Reuchlin's. Debate in humanist circles continued up into the 17th century, but the situation remained undecided for several centuries. (See [[Pronunciation of Ancient Greek in teaching]].)
===The 19th century=== A renewed interest in the issues of reconstructed pronunciation arose during the 19th century. On the one hand, the new science of [[historical linguistics]], based on the method of comparative reconstruction, took a vivid interest in Greek. It soon established beyond any doubt that Greek was descended in parallel with many other languages from the common source of the [[Indo-European languages|Indo-European]] proto-language. This had important consequences for how its phonological system must be reconstructed. At the same time, continued work in philology and archeology was bringing to light an ever-growing corpus of non-standard, non-literary and non-classical Greek writings, e.g. inscriptions and later also papyri. These added considerably to what could be known about the development of the language. On the other hand, there was a revival of academic life in Greece after the [[Greek War of Independence|establishment of the Greek state]] in 1830, and scholars in Greece were at first reluctant to accept the seemingly foreign idea that Greek should have been pronounced so differently from what they knew.
Comparative linguistics led to a picture of ancient Greek that more or less corroborated Erasmus' view, though with some modifications. It soon became clear, for instance, that the pattern of long and short vowels observed in Greek was mirrored in similar oppositions in other languages and thus had to be a common inheritance (see [[apophony|Ablaut]]); that Greek {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|υ}}}} had to have been {{IPA|[u]}} at some stage because it regularly corresponded to {{IPA|[u]}} in all other Indo-European languages (cf. Gr. {{lang|grc|μῦς}} : Lat. ''{{lang|la|mūs}}''); that many instances of {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|η}}}} had earlier been {{IPA|[aː]}} (cf. Gr. {{lang|grc|μήτηρ}} : Lat. ''{{lang|la|māter}}''); that Greek {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ου}}}} sometimes stood in words that had been lengthened from {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ο}}}} and therefore must have been pronounced {{IPA|[oː]}} at some stage (the same holds analogically for {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ε}}}} and {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ει}}}}, which must have been {{IPA|[eː]}}), and so on. For the consonants, historical linguistics established the originally plosive nature of both the aspirates {{angbr|{{lang|grc|φ,θ,χ}}}} {{IPA|[pʰ, tʰ, kʰ]}} and the mediae {{angbr|{{lang|grc|β, δ, γ}}}} {{IPA|[b, d, ɡ]}}, which were recognised to be a direct continuation of similar sounds in Indo-European (reconstructed {{PIE|*bʰ, *dʰ, *gʰ}} and {{PIE|*b, *d, *g}}). It was also recognised that the word-initial ''spiritus asper'' was most often a reflex of earlier {{PIE|*s}} (cf. Gr. {{lang|grc|ἑπτά}} : Lat. ''{{lang|la|septem}}''), which was believed to have been weakened to {{IPA|[h]}} in pronunciation. Work was also done reconstructing the linguistic background to the rules of ancient Greek versification, especially in Homer, which shed important light on the phonology regarding syllable structure and accent. Scholars also described and explained the regularities in the development of consonants and vowels under processes of assimilation, reduplication, compensatory lengthening etc.
While comparative linguistics could in this way firmly establish that a certain source state, roughly along the Erasmian model, had once obtained, and that significant changes had to have occurred later, during the development towards Modern Greek, the comparative method had less to say about the question ''when'' these changes took place. Erasmus had been eager to find a pronunciation system that corresponded most closely to the written letters, and it was now natural to assume that the reconstructed sound system was that which obtained at the time when Greek orthography was in its formative period. For a time, it was taken for granted that this would also have been the pronunciation valid for all the period of classical literature. However, it was perfectly possible that the pronunciation of the living language had begun to move on from that reconstructed system towards that of Modern Greek, possibly already quite early during antiquity.
In this context, the freshly emerging evidence from the non-standard inscriptions became of decisive importance. Critics of the Erasmian reconstruction drew attention to the systematic patterns of spelling mistakes made by scribes. These mistakes showed that scribes had trouble distinguishing between the orthographically correct spellings for certain words, for instance involving {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ι}}}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|η}}}}, and {{angle bracket|{{lang|grc|ει}}}}. This provided evidence that these vowels had already begun to merge in the living speech of the period. While some scholars in Greece were quick to emphasise these findings in order to cast doubt on the Erasmian system as a whole, some western European scholars tended to downplay them, explaining early instances of such orthographical aberrations as either isolated exceptions or influences from non-Attic, non-standard dialects. The resulting debate, as it was conducted during the 19th century, finds its expression in, for instance, the works of {{Harvtxt|Jannaris|1897}} and {{Harvtxt|Papadimitrakopoulos|1889}} on the anti-Erasmian side, and of [[Friedrich Blass]] (1870) on the pro-Erasmian side.
It was not until the early 20th century and the work of G. Chatzidakis, a linguist often credited with having first introduced the methods of modern historical linguistics into the Greek academic establishment, that the validity of the comparative method and its reconstructions for Greek began to be widely accepted among Greek scholars too. The international consensus view that had been reached by the early and mid-20th century is represented in the works of {{Harvtxt|Sturtevant|1940}} and {{Harvtxt|Allen|1987}}.
===More recent developments=== Since the 1970s and 1980s, several scholars have attempted a systematic re-evaluation of the inscriptional and papyrological evidence (Smith 1972, Teodorsson 1974, 1977, 1978; Gignac 1976; Threatte 1980, summary in Horrocks 1999). According to their results, many of the relevant phonological changes can be dated fairly early, reaching well into the classical period, and the period of the Koiné can be characterised as one of very rapid phonological change. Many of the changes in vowel quality are now dated to some time between the 5th and the 1st centuries BC, while those in the consonants are assumed to have been completed by the 4th century AD. However, there is still considerable debate over precise dating, and it is still not clear to what degree, and for how long, different pronunciation systems would have persisted side by side within the Greek speech community. The resulting majority view today is that a phonological system roughly along Erasmian lines can still be assumed to have been valid for the period of classical Attic literature, but biblical and other post-classical [[Koine Greek]] is likely to have been spoken with a pronunciation that already approached that of Modern Greek in many crucial respects.
Recently, there has been one attempt at a more radically revisionist, anti-Erasmian reconstruction, proposed by the theologian and philologist Chrys Caragounis, Professor Emeritus at [[Lund University]] (1995, 2004). On the basis of the inscriptional record, Caragounis dates virtually all relevant vowel changes into or before the early classical period. He relies heavily upon Threatte and Gignac for data from the papyri, but he provides little if any actual interaction with their own markedly different analyses of the very same historical data. He also argues for a very early fricative status of the aspirate and medial consonants, and casts doubt on the validity of the vowel-length and accent distinctions in the spoken language in general. These views are currently isolated within the field.

====Ancient Greek sources====
=====Aristotle===== ''{{cite wikisource|last=''Aristotle|title=Περί Ποιητικής|language=Classical Greek''|trans_title=''Poetics''|wslanguage=el|at=section 1456b, lines 20–34|ref=harv}}'' {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} All speech consists of these categories: element [letter], syllable, conjunction, noun, verb, inflection, phrase.
A '''letter''' is an indivisible sound — not any sound, but a sound from which a compound sound [syllable] can naturally be made, since the sounds of animals are also indivisible, and I call none of them a letter. The categories of sound are sounding [vowels], half-sounding [semivowels: fricatives and sonorants], and unsounded [silent or mute: stop].
These categories are the '''vowel''', which has audible sound but no contact [between lips or between tongue and the inside of the mouth]; the '''semivowel''', which has audible sound and contact (for example ''s'' and ''r''); and the '''mute''', which has contact and no sound by itself, becoming audible only with [letters] that have a sound (for example ''g'' and ''d'').
[Letters] differ in the shape of the mouth and place [in the mouth], in '''thickness''' and '''thinness''' [aspiration and unaspiration], in length and shortness — and still more in '''sharpness''' and '''depth''' and '''middle''' [high and low pitch, and pitch between the two]: but theorizing about these things in detail is the job of those who study [poetic] meter. {{col-break}} {{lang|grc|Τῆς δὲ λέξεως ἁπάσης τάδ᾽ ἐστὶ τὰ μέρη, στοιχεῖον συλλαβὴ σύνδεσμος ὄνομα ῥῆμα ἄρθρον πτῶσις λόγος.}}
{{lang|grc|'''Στοιχεῖον''' μὲν οὖν ἐστιν φωνὴ ἀδιαίρετος, οὐ πᾶσα δὲ ἀλλ᾽ ἐξ ἧς πέφυκε συνθετὴ γίγνεσθαι φωνή· καὶ γὰρ τῶν θηρίων εἰσὶν ἀδιαίρετοι φωναί, ὧν οὐδεμίαν λέγω στοιχεῖον. Ταύτης δὲ μέρη τό τε φωνῆεν καὶ τὸ ἡμίφωνον καὶ ἄφωνον.}}
{{lang|grc|Ἔστιν δὲ ταῦτα '''φωνῆεν''' μὲν <τὸ> ἄνευ προσβολῆς ἔχον φωνὴν ἀκουστήν, '''ἡμίφωνον''' δὲ τὸ μετὰ προσβολῆς ἔχον φωνὴν ἀκουστήν, οἷον τὸ Σ καὶ τὸ Ρ, '''ἄφωνον''' δὲ τὸ μετὰ προσβολῆς καθ᾽ αὑτὸ μὲν οὐδεμίαν ἔχον φωνήν, μετὰ δὲ τῶν ἐχόντων τινὰ φωνὴν γινόμενον ἀκουστόν, οἷον τὸ Γ καὶ τὸ Δ.}}
{{lang|grc|ταῦτα δὲ διαφέρει σχήμασίν τε τοῦ στόματος καὶ τόποις καὶ '''δασύτητι''' καὶ '''ψιλότητι''' καὶ μήκει καὶ βραχύτητι ἔτι δὲ '''ὀξύτητι''' καὶ '''βαρύτητι''' καὶ '''τῷ μέσῳ''': περὶ ὧν καθ᾽ ἕκαστον ἐν τοῖς μετρικοῖς προσήκει θεωρεῖν.}} {{col-end}}
=====Dionysius Thrax===== {{cite book |last=Dionysius Thrax |authorlink=Dionysius Thrax |script-title=''Ars Grammatica'' (Τέχνη Γραμματική) |trans-title=Art of Grammar |language=Koine Greek |chapterurl=https://archive.org/stream/dionysiithracis00merxgoog#page/n114/mode/2up |chapter=ς´ περὶ στοιχείου |trans-chapter=6. On the Sound |via=[[The Internet Archive]] |accessdate=20 May 2016 |ref=harv }} {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} There are 24 '''letters''', from ''a'' to ''ō''.... Letters are also called elements [of speech] because they have an order and classification.
Of these, seven are vowels: ''a, e, ē, i, o, y, ō''. They are called '''vowels''' because they form a complete sound by themselves.
Two of the vowels are '''long''' (''ē'' and ''ō''), two are '''short''' (''e'' and ''o''), and three are two-timed (''a i y''). They are called '''two-timed''' since they can be lengthened and shortened.
Five are prefixable vowels: ''a, e, ē, o, ō''. They are called '''prefixable''' because they form a complete syllable when prefixed before ''i'' and ''y'': for instance, ''ai au''. Two are '''suffixable''': ''i'' and ''y''. And ''y'' is sometimes prefixable before ''i'', as in ''myia'' and ''harpyia''.
Six are '''diphthongs''': ''ai au ei eu oi ou''.
The remaining seventeen letters are consonants [pronounced-with]: ''b, g, d, z, th, k, l, m, n, x, p, r, s, t, ph, kh, ps''. They are called '''consonants''' because they do not have a sound on their own, but they form a complete sound when arranged with vowels.
Of these, eight are semivowels: ''z, x, ps, l, m, n, r, s''. They are called '''semivowels''', because, though a little weaker than the vowels, they still sound pleasant in hummings and hissings.
Nine are mutes: ''b, g, d, k, p, t, th, ph, kh''. They are called '''mute''', because, more than the others, they sound bad, just as we call a performer of tragedy who sounds bad ''voiceless''. Three of these are '''thin''' (''k, p, t''), three are '''thick''' (''th, ph, kh''), and three of them are middle [intermediate] (''b, g, d''). They are called '''middle''', because they are thicker than the thin [mutes], but thinner than the thick [mutes]. And ''b'' is [the mute] between ''p'' and ''ph'', ''g'' between ''k'' and ''kh'', and ''d'' between ''th'' and ''t''.
The thick [mutes] alternate with the thin ones, ''ph'' with ''p'', as in [an example from the Odyssey]; ''kh'' with ''k'': [another example from the Odyssey]; ''th'' with ''t'': [an example from the Iliad]. {{col-break}} {{lang|grc|'''γράμματά''' ἐστιν εἰκοσιτέσσαρα ἀπο τοῦ α μέχρι τοῦ ω.... τὰ [γράμματα] δὲ αὐτὰ καὶ στοιχεῖα καλεῖται διὰ τὸ ἔχειν στοῖχόν τινα καὶ τάξιν.}}
{{lang|grc|τούτων φωνήεντα μέν ἐστιν ἑπτά· α ε η ι ο υ ω. '''φωνήεντα''' δὲ λέγεται, ὅτι φωνὴν ἀφ᾽ ἑαυτῶν ἀποτελεῖ....}}
{{lang|grc|τῶν δὲ φωνηέντων '''μακρὰ''' μέν ἐστι δύο, η καὶ ω, '''βραχέα''' δύο, ε καὶ ο, δίχρονα τρία, α ι υ. '''δίχρονα''' δὲ λέγεται, ἐπεὶ ἐκτείνεται καί συστέλλεται.}}
{{lang|grc|προτακτικὰ φωνήεντα πέντε· α ε η ο ω. '''προτακτικὰ''' δὲ λέγεται, ὅτι προτασσόμενα τοῦ ι καὶ υ συλλαβὴν ἀποτελεῖ, οἷον αι αυ. '''ὑποτακτικὰ''' δύο· ι καὶ υ. καὶ τὸ υ δὲ ἐνιότε προτακτικόν ἐστι τοῦ ι, ὡς ἐν τῶι μυῖα καὶ ἅρπυια.}}
{{lang|grc|'''δίφθογγοι''' δέ εἰσιν ἕξ· αι αυ ει ευ οι ου.}}
{{lang|grc|σύμφωνα δὲ τὰ λοιπὰ ἑπτακαίδεκα· β γ δ ζ θ κ λ μ ν ξ π ρ σ τ φ χ ψ. '''σύμφωνα''' δὲ λέγονται, ὅτι αὐτὰ μὲν καθ᾽ ἑαυτὰ φωνὴν οὐκ ἔχει, συντασσόμενα δὲ μετὰ τῶν φωνηέντων φωνὴν ἀποτελεῖ.}}
{{lang|grc|τούτων ἡμίφωνα μέν ἐστιν ὀκτώ· ζ ξ ψ λ μ ν ρ σ. '''ἡμίφωνα''' δὲ λέγεται, ὅτι παρ᾽ ὅσον ἧττον τῶν φωνηέντων εὔφωνα καθέστηκεν ἔν τε τοῖς μυγμοῖς καὶ σιγμοῖς.}}
{{lang|grc|ἄφωνα δέ ἐστιν ἐννέα· β γ δ κ π τ θ φ χ. '''ἄφωνα''' δὲ λέγεται, ὅτι μᾶλλον τῶν ἄλλων ἐστὶν κακόφωνα, ὥσπερ ἄφωνον λέγομεν τὸν τραγωιδὸν τὸν κακόφωνον. τούτων '''ψιλὰ''' μέν ἐστι τρία, κ π τ, '''δασέα''' τρία, θ φ χ, μέσα δὲ τούτων τρία, β γ δ. '''μέσα''' δὲ εἴρηται, ὅτι τῶν μὲν ψιλῶν ἐστι δασύτερα, τῶν δὲ δασέων ψιλότερα. καὶ ἔστι τὸ μὲν β μέσον τοῦ π καὶ φ, τὸ δὲ γ μέσον τοῦ κ καὶ χ, τὸ δὲ δ μέσον τοῦ θ καὶ τ.}}
{{lang|grc|ἀντιστοιχεῖ δὲ τὰ δασέα τοῖς ψιλοῖς, τῶι μὲν π τὸ φ, οὕτως·}} *{{lang|grc|ἀλλά μοι '''εἴφ᾽ ὅπηι''' [εἰπέ ὅπῃ] ἔσχες ἰὼν εὐεργέα νῆα ([[s:el:Οδύσσεια/ι#v270|Odyssey 4.279]]),}} {{lang|grc|τῶι δὲ κ τὸ χ·}} *{{lang|grc|'''αὐτίχ᾽ ὁ''' [αὐτίκα ὁ] μὲν χλαῖνάν τε χιτῶνά τε ἕννυτ᾽ Ὀδυσσεύς ([[s:el:Οδύσσεια/ε#v220|Odyssey 5.229]]),}} {{lang|grc|τὸ δὲ θ τῶι τ·}} *{{lang|grc|ὣς '''ἔφαθ᾽· οἱ''' [ἔφατο οἱ] δ᾽ ἄρα πάντες ἀκὴν ἐγένοντο σιωπῆι ([[s:el:Ιλιάς/Γ#v90|Iliad 4.95]]).}} {{col-end}} {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} In addition, three consonants are double: ''z, x, ps''. They are called '''double''' because each one of them is made up of two consonants: ''z'' from ''s'' and ''d'', ''x'' from ''k'' and ''s'', and ''ps'' from ''p'' and ''s''.
There are four unchangeable [consonants]: ''l, m, n, r''. They are called unchangeable because they do not change in the future [tense]s of verbs and in the declensions of nouns. They are also called '''liquids'''. {{col-break}} {{lang|grc|ἔτι δὲ τῶν συμφώνων διπλᾶ μέν ἐστι τρία· ζ ξ ψ. '''διπλᾶ''' δὲ εἴρηται, ὅτι ἓν ἕκαστον αὐτῶν ἐκ δύο συμφώνων σύγκειται, τὸ μὲν ζ ἐκ τοῦ σ καὶ δ, τὸ δὲ ξ ἐκ τοῦ κ καὶ σ, τὸ δὲ ψ ἐκ τοῦ π καὶ σ.}}
{{lang|grc|ἀμετάβολα τέσσαρα· λ μ ν ρ. ἀμετὰβολα δὲ λέγεται, ὅτι οὐ μεταβάλλει ἐν τοῖς μέλλουσι τῶν ῥημάτων οὐδὲ ἐν ταῖς κλίσεσι τῶν ὀνομάτων. τὰ δὲ αὐτὰ καὶ '''ὑγρὰ''' καλεῖται.}} {{col-end}}
